Comparison with other states: The expert analyzed data from the Grapevine report produced by the Center for the Study of Education Policy at Illinois State University to compare New Jersey's investment in higher education with other states. This comparison revealed that New Jersey was not the only state to decrease its aid for higher education in the specified time frame.
Analysis of state appropriations: The expert examined the state appropriations for higher education in New Jersey over the last decade. According to the State Higher Education Executive Officers data, New Jersey's appropriations have actually increased by 37 percent from 2000 to 2010. This analysis contradicts the claim made by Republican state Sen. Tom Kean Jr.
Consideration of inflation: The expert also took into account the impact of inflation on educational appropriations. They mentioned that the State Higher Education Executive Officers use an index specifically intended to adjust for the increases in costs for colleges and universities. This index helps provide a more accurate picture of the percentage increase in educational appropriations.
Verification through multiple measures: The expert utilized various measures of state support for higher education to verify the authenticity of the claim. These measures showed consistent increases of more than 30 percent over the last decade, further contradicting the claim made by Sen. Kean.
